tripleo_common/image/image_uploader.py.message: The intent is to block on the response here, but tags request has been made can still be ongoing until tags_f.result() is called. When docker.io is taking seconds to respond this saving can really add up.

Are you sure this is not causing a performance regression? I recall benchmarking a noticable improvement doing the manifest and tags gets in parallel, since inspect is called many times in a prepare run. My aim here was to be faster than "skopeo inspect" which was slower because it was doing three get calls in serial

Another potential optimization is to add some boolean arguments to inspect so that the tags and the config are not fetched when only the manifest is required (this could help speed the many calls to _image_exists, _image_digest)

OK, I see a slight performance improvement with this change, which would be from removing the thread overhead for an attempt at concurrency which isn't actually concurrent. My testing shows for a single inspect to docker.io:

master: 4.6s
this:   4.1s
skopeo: 7.8s

I think the main reason skopeo is slower is because it doesn't use the authenticated session for the tags call, so it has to re-authenticate.

There might be some extra time to save by concurrently fetching the manifest and tags correctly.

Yea the reuse of a session should help things. I can see what you were trying to do by starting the tag call witht he manifest call but if the manifest call was fast, there's really very little improvement to be had because it'd just stop here until tags_f.result() finished.  I'm going to investigate a bit more around here because I'm wondering if this call is getting more expensive over time.

Is cyborg dead in the water if it can't talk to Placement and/or Nova? Or will handle failures gracefully and keep trying to communicate?

[Later] Quickly skimming through the code, I see zero exception handling, so I guess this is an open issue either way.

There are two ways API calls through an SDK Adapter can raise exceptions:
- If the service responds with HTTP status >=400. You can switch these off by passing raise_exc=False to the Adapter creation and/or individual requests, in which case you get back a Response object just like for successful calls, and you can manually check the Response.status_code. This is how we've got Nova set up.
- If communication with the service is broken. This can happen if SDK/KSA can't even figure out who to talk to (like if the service catalog is busted); or if the service is completely down. These should always be subclasses of keystoneauth1.exceptions.ClientException. You can't switch them off like you can with the above.

Now, when you create a Connection, passing strict_proxies=True causes SDK to poke at the service to make sure it's actually alive, and raise ServiceDiscoveryException if it's not. If you don't do this check, and the service is dead (second bullet above), you won't find out until the first time you try to issue an API request; and then you'll get a 5xx, either via exception or Response depending on raise_exc (first bullet above).

So for cyborg, you have to decide which approach you want to take. Given what I know about how cyborg works, I think you probably want to use strict_proxies=True and make your client __init__s sleep and retry until the target service becomes active [1]. Otherwise, when a cloud is being brought up, if cyborg comes up first (before placement and/or nova), it will barf trying to perform API requests against those services.

[1] Certain exceptions like bogus service catalog should cause you to fail right away, because they won't clear up by themselves. But that's a refinement you can iterate on later.

> - If the service responds with HTTP status >=400. You can switch
 > these off by passing raise_exc=False to the Adapter creation and/or
 > individual requests, in which case you get back a Response object
 > just like for successful calls, and you can manually check the
 > Response.status_code. This is how we've got Nova set up.

I think I was wrong about the default -- when going through the SDK, raise_exc=False is set by default [1].

...um, and it looks like it doesn't honor an override [2]. That's a bug.

So if you wanted the raise-on-status>=400 behavior, you could use openstack.exceptions.raise_from_response() (note that you'll get subclasses of SDKException in that case); but I would still recommend just checking the status codes manually and reacting accordingly.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/src/branch/master/openstack/proxy.py#L87
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/src/branch/master/openstack/proxy.py#L96

nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py.message:
Unrelated, but while we're looking, and I think this came up in IRC discussion, this method is used by the API (GET /servers/{server_id}/migrations) to list in-progress live migrations. The method we're changing above is only used by the resource tracker.

For this method, 'accepted' should probably be in the list since it's a live migration status. The method is likely biased to what the API lists so that you can abort or force-complete an in-progress live migration. I'm not sure if 'accepted' is really any different from 'queued' except for where it's set (former in conductor, latter in compute). The semantics for what you can do with those are probably different in the API though (maybe you can't cancel an "accepted" live migration, but seems you should be able to and this was probably just an oversight).

Anyway, in a follow up change it would probably be beneficial to document where/how this is used and how it's tightly coupled to API behavior so we'd have to be careful about ever changing this one.

> Unrelated, but while we're looking, and I think this came up in IRC
 > discussion, this method is used by the API (GET /servers/{server_id}/migrations)
 > to list in-progress live migrations. The method we're changing
 > above is only used by the resource tracker.

Yeah, Sean brought this up on IRC. This is all correct - this method is only used by that server_migrations API, while the previous one is only used by the resource tracker.

 > For this method, 'accepted' should probably be in the list since
 > it's a live migration status. The method is likely biased to what
 > the API lists so that you can abort or force-complete an
 > in-progress live migration. I'm not sure if 'accepted' is really
 > any different from 'queued' except for where it's set (former in
 > conductor, latter in compute). The semantics for what you can do
 > with those are probably different in the API though (maybe you
 > can't cancel an "accepted" live migration, but seems you should be
 > able to and this was probably just an oversight).

I don't think the mechanics we currently have would allow us to cancel an accepted migration - to do so, we pop it off the 
_waiting_live_migrations dict [1], but we only put it there after we've set it to 'queued' [2].
 
 > Anyway, in a follow up change it would probably be beneficial to
 > document where/how this is used and how it's tightly coupled to API
 > behavior so we'd have to be careful about ever changing this one.

Yeah - your todo on L4408 would be good to implement in general.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/0ce66605e16aca85df97acdd8c459802fcdb9aa0/nova/compute/manager.py#L7185
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/0ce66605e16aca85df97acdd8c459802fcdb9aa0/nova/compute/manager.py#L7102

This isn't even used for live migration. If you consider force-complete or cancelling an in-progress live migration though, we probably should set this in _post_live_migration in the ComputeManager because trying to cancel or force-complete at that point isn't going to work.

swift/proxy/controllers/obj.py.message:
Previously, whenever the client sent a Content-Length header, we'd calculate an expected_frag_size and send it as X-Backend-Obj-Content-Length (which would get used in some fallocate call down in the object-server).

Significantly, this would happen even if the client *was actually sending* a chunk-encoded transfer. (Since the Transfer-Encoding header trumps Content-Length -- see https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-3.3.3, item 3, paragraph 3. Jesus, that's a lot of threes.)

Now, we'll let message_length() return None in that case, and rely on the earlier invocation over in check_object_creation() (called as part of the main PUT method) to enforce that any Transfer-Encoding *only* specifies 'chunked'.

I think actually we want the union of what is not-blocked by isolcpus and what is allowed by ovs-dpdk masks:

    ovs_dpdk_cpus=$(comm -12 <(echo "$cpumask") <(echo "$syscpus")

    cpuset=$(echo "$ovs_dpdk_cpus" "$podcpus" | sort -u)

We could skip installing cgroup-tools and get away with:

    mkdir -p /sys/fs/cgroup/cpuset/osh-openvswitch

we still need to run via 'cgexec' which I think is also part of cgtools

user@vm:~$ cgexec
The program 'cgexec' is currently not installed. To run 'cgexec' please ask your administrator to install the package 'cgroup-tools'

We actually should copy the default value here:

    cat /sys/fs/cgroup/cpuset/cpuset.mems > /sys/fs/cgroup/cpuset/osh-openvswitch/cpuset.mems

skip cpu, and just use mkdir

    mkdir -p /sys/fs/cgroup/cpuset/osh-openvswitch

add the current task to the newly created cgroup

    echo $$ > /sys/fs/cgroup/cpuset/osh-openvswitch/tasks

do we want to include this entire block in the big "if"?

    {{- if .Values.conf.ovs_dpdk.enabled }}
maybe add a comment about ovs_dpdk_cpus, like "cpus allowed by pmd cpu mask and lcore mask"?

This ends up putting two CPUs (the last ovs_dpdk_cpu and the first podcpu) on the same line. Easiest workaround might be:

    cpuset=$(echo $ovs_dpdk_cpus $podcpus | tr ' ' '\n' | sort -u)
Can we just add all the cores on the server to the cpuset? pmd_cpu_mask will choose the right ones from all the cores.
Ok, I think that will be good. Will update the code
may don't need to get the isolated cpu cores, because we don't use this parameter in this script.

If we drop the isolcpus, maybe we could change this condition to:

    if [[ -n ${PMD_CPU_MASK} || -n ${LCORE_MASK} ]]

(and add LCORE_MASK= back above)

This new created cpuset cgroup inherits from it's parent cgroup(the root cgroup). It means that the new osh-openvswitch cgroup already contains all the cores. So I think we don't have to set cpuset.cpus and cpuset.mems explicitly. What we need to do is just create the new osh-openvswitch cgroup, because the default valaues are already what we want.

When tested in a few places (including with the openvswitch image), cpuset.mems and cpuset.cpus are empty on creation, and need to be explicitly populated, otherwise you get ENOSPC errors when actually assigning tasks to the cgroup. The cgroup documentation seems to support this.

But I think you are right that we could do the same thing for both, just copy settings from root cgroup.
what about the non-ovsdpdk use case?

This check needs to be made more robust. 2 changes needs to go in.
1. When I ran for component ingress in openstack namespace, it picked up mariabd-ingress pods instead of a ingress. This would produce false successes and failures. I think we should check for both component and application. So it should look like
POD=$(kubectl -n $NS get pod -l application=$APPLICATION,component=$COMPONENT | grep Running | awk '{print $1}')
e.g test_netpol openstack keystone api heat-api.openstack.svc.cluster.local fail

2. Need to change one of the grep's to "| grep -m 1 Running" because if there are a multiple pods matching the grep criterion, there will be a list and the next command (line 26) will fail.

Is should be as following else we may have issue if  the component name is not part of pod name.
POD=$(kubectl -n $NS get pod -l application=$APP,component=$COMPONENT | grep -m1 Running | awk '{print $1}')

I'd prefer to switch these to align with the tests.

Example:
test_netpol openstack keystone(application) api(component) mariadb.openstack.svc.cluster.local:3306 success

As the bug report discussion, the root problem has been fixed since https://review.openstack.org/#/c/392643/

TBH, I hesitate to remove these files from compute node because migration operations (including resize) can be failed and operators need to salvage instance info from such files sometimes.

Thanks for your advice, I saw the above that commit, but I later found that the impact of live migration is not the console.log, but the instance directory, this directory will be checked before live migration and then migration will fail, I updated at bug #1694913.
If keep the instance directory, after the instance is deleted, it will still exist because nova does not know the existence of this directory on other host.
Do we need to keep these directories and files?
When using non-shared storage, directories and files will be deleted after revert on destination host, but with shared storage, they will not be deleted.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: the same comments as the commit message.
You're going to test whether this is called, at a minimum
How does this work with shared instance path?

Libvirt with flat/qcow2 backend uses shared network file storage, it is still considered non-shared storage in nova, that is determined by images_type.
Look https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/libvirt/imagebackend.py#L360

And if destroy_disks flag (L3676) is True, driver.destroy will delete instance files and instance disk, In shared storage like RBD, it should not delete instance disk，so here is just to delete the instance directory.
Look https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L1009

self._is_instance_storage_shared returns True in such case (it uses a special additional request to the source node, https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/manager.py#L673). Because that destroy_disks is False (sorry my mistake in the previous comment). As the result driver.destroy does not delete instance files - for shared network file storage.

But with your changes it does. Maybe it's right, but it should be proven.

This doesn't seem correct. As Feodor said, all of this logic is handled at the virt driver layers and for shared storage like rbd, we shouldn't be deleting the instance files when we move the instance around.

If libvirt with flat/qcow2 backend uses shared network file storage for instance files, then destroy_disks flag (L3676) is True, and therefore driver.destroy keeps instance files. But here you delete them. Is it correct? How does Nova handles revert_resize after that? And if all is correct, why would not just set destroy_disks flag to True?
Only libvirt driver implements this function, in libvirt driver, only rbd image backend is shared block storage, but rbd will not have shared instance path, so here will work correctly

openstack/horizon/horizon.spec.j2.message:
Hm, I am not sure about this. First I think this should be using some form of the "py2pkg/py3" template macro. But then, I think in Queens all of this was python2 based. Now this package is python3 (not singlespec). Should we really have a python3 package obsolete a python2 package?
Maybe others can chime in.

I think I (finally) got the point :o)
So proper place to get rid of python-django_openstack_auth is in Queens which would look exactly like here (plus the macro). The problem is that in SOC we will skip this package and we still want to remove the old python2 version. There is no python3 version of django_openstack_auth so the best I can think of is py2() in both Queens and Rocky branches.
Yup. I'm not even sure if master needs any of this. I haven't found any python3 package for django_openstack_auth. So I will submit a different one for Q/R/S.

I think the python2 removal should be done in a different way. It's totally valid to have a python2 *and* python3 version of a package installed in parallel. So having this in master is wrong.
You should add this (for python2) to everything < master (only master switched to py3).
Does that make sense?
I think you need a provides/obsoletes. See https://en.opensuse.org/openSUSE:Package_dependencies#Merging_a_package

Do you mean that horizon package should provide "virtual" python-django_openstack_auth? Is there some package which requires that? I don't think so (since there is no new version of this package at all). This "Obsoletes" is here just to ensure proper cleanup of old packages.
